https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Artificial intelligence (AI), in its broadest sense, is intelligence exhibited by machines, particularly computer systems, i.e. the capability of machines/computers to imitate intelligent human behaviour without being explicitly programmed. By extension, a field of research in computer science that develops and studies methods and software that enable machines to perceive their environment and uses learning and intelligence to take actions that maximize their chances of achieving defined goals.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Wikipedia.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Artificial intelligence (AI), in its broadest sense, is intelligence exhibited by machines, particularly computer systems, i.e. the capability of machines/computers to imitate intelligent human behaviour without being explicitly programmed. By extension, a field of research in computer science that develops and studies methods and software that enable machines to perceive their environment and uses learning and intelligence to take actions that maximize their chances of achieving defined goals.

Deep learning is a subset of machine learning methods that utilize neural networks for representation learning, i.e. simulate the complex decision-making power of the human brain. The field takes inspiration from biological neuroscience and is centered around stacking artificial neurons into layers and 'training' them to process data. The adjective 'deep' refers to the use of multiple layers (ranging from three to several hundred or thousands) in the network.'

Machine learning (ML) is the field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalize to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.
